scenario:
Lockheed Martin (LMT) builds America's only two fifth-generation "stealth" fighter jets, the F-22 Raptor and the F-35 Lightning II. However, the F-22 was introduced 20 years ago and the F-35 10 years ago, making them less cutting-edge. In contrast, China has demonstrated two new sixth-generation fighter jets, one possibly built by Chengdu Aircraft and the other by Shenyang Aircraft. 

The appearance of these Chinese jets suggests that China is making progress in sixth-generation fighter technology, with a goal of fielding these planes by 2035. This has sparked a sixth-generation arms race between the US and China. The US Air Force is developing the Next Generation Air Dominance (NGAD) fighter, with Lockheed Martin and Boeing (BA) remaining in the running. 

The Air Force hopes to get NGAD in the air in the 2030s, roughly the same timeline as China. This suggests that the Pentagon will continue to fund the NGAD program, despite cost concerns. Lockheed Martin is considered the odds-on favorite to build any new stealth fighter jets, based on its experience building the F-22 and F-35. 

Boeing's defense business may remain in the race due to the potential for a large contract to build up to 200 warplanes at $700 million each, worth $140 billion total. This could be a strong incentive for Boeing to continue participating in the NGAD program, at least until it loses the contract to Lockheed Martin.
